topic.title: Discover Your Powershell Version in 3 Easy Steps: A Comprehensive Guide

section.p: Whether you're a seasoned IT professional or just getting started, you can aid with compatibility and troubleshooting by checking the PowerShell version on your Windows 10 or 11 machine.

section.title: How to Verify the Version of PowerShell in Windows 10/11
section.p: Powershell is a robust solution powered by scripting language and command line shell for cross-platform task automation. Instead of the.NET Framework, PowerShell uses the latest versions and is compatible with Windows, Linux, and macOS. PowerShell support depends on its.NET version.
You may check the PowerShell version on your Windows 10/11 PC in several methods, such as:.

section.title: Method 1:
section.p: Use the Power User Menu to Launch PowerShellpening PowerShell from the Power User Menu
Start PowerShell: To launch PowerShell, locate it in the Start menu or select "Windows PowerShell" or "Windows PowerShell (Admin)" from the Power User menu by pressing Win + X.

body.p: Verify Version: Press Enter after entering Get-Host | Select-Object Version in PowerShell.
You can also use $PSVersionTable to verify the same thing.

These are a few quick ways to find out what version of PowerShell is on your Windows 10 or 11 machine. Updating PowerShell guarantees you access to the most recent features, security updates, and bug fixes, which improves the security and efficiency of your system.

Always make sure you verify the PowerShell version on a regular basis, particularly prior to executing scripts or attempting complex configurations, to prevent incompatibilities and guarantee seamless operations.

Keeping Windows PowerShell installed and downloading PowerShell 7.2 can help you avoid upgrading due to feature parity issues. Since PowerShell 7 and later are no longer Windows native, you'll need to test all of your scripts before switching to 7 or 7.2. Adaptations are needed for some modules.
